parts: Name this trumpeter, who collaborated with arranger Gil Evans on the album Kind of Blue.
On Kind of Blue, Miles Davis popularized this style of jazz, pioneered by George Russell, which replaces harmonic progressions with progressions of the namesake scales.
This later collaboration between Miles Davis and Gil Evans includes adaptations of music by Manuel de Falla and Joaquin Rodrigo, including the latter's Concierto de Aranjuez.
Name this cursed house in Greek myth, named for the father of Agamemnon and Menelaus.
Atreus was the grandson of this figure, who attempted to feed his son Pelops to the gods. He was punished in the afterlife by never being able to quench his thirst or hunger.

Atreus had a power struggle with this brother of his, who was forced to eat the flesh of his children and fathered Aegisthus with his daughter Pelopia. This man lost his kingdom when Zeus caused the Sun to move back in the sky.

Cole is often considered the founder of this school of 19th-century landscape painting. Its other members included Frederic Church and Asher Durand, and it is named after a geographic feature in New York.
This four-part Thomas Cole series, illustrating "Childhood," "Youth," "Manhood," and "Old Age," depicts a man as he travels down an allegorical river watched over by an angel.

This painting from Cole's The Course of Empire series shows a city under attack. Many buildings and boats are on fire in this painting, which also features a large, headless statue overlooking the scene.

A recent National Geographic list ranked this country the most at risk from climate change. This country, which often suffers floods of the Ganges, Brahmaputra, and Meghna Rivers, has its capital at Dhaka.

This country in the Pacific, whose economy is largely driven by the sale of top-level domain names, is at particular risk from global warming because its highest point is only 4.6 meters above sea level. This country's capital is Funafuti.

While president of this low-lying country, Mohamed Nasheed desperately tried to prevent the 2009 Copenhagen Climate Summit from collapsing through a publicity campaign that included the world's first underwater cabinet meeting.

answers: National Grange of the Order of Patrons of Husbandry [or Grangers; or Grange]
Munn v. Illinois [accept in either order]
railroads [or freight trains; or railway; etc.]
parts: Name this fraternal farm organization that was founded after the Civil War. Aaron Grosh and Oliver Hudson Kelley were two of the eight original founders of this group.
The decision in this court case was a great victory for the Grangers before it was weakened by Wabash v. Illinois. This case ruled that Illinois' regulation of grain elevators was constitutional.

Many of the so called "Granger Laws" were aimed at regulating fare prices on these networks. The Interstate Commerce Commission was originally created to regulate these networks, notable examples of which were connected at Promontory Point in Utah.
Name this process of polynomial long division, which is typically taught by drawing a box around the dividend.

Since the remainder of synthetic division is a ratio of two polynomials, it is classified as one of these functions. The numbers of this name are capable of being expressed as a ratio of two whole numbers.
Some rational functions have singularities or discontinuities described by this adjective, in which the function is regular around the singularity and the limit from either side is finite and equal.
Give this term from the Dutch for "farmer" that identifies a people who fought two namesake wars against Britain in modern-day South Africa.

This South African Prime Minister worked tirelessly to bridge the gap between the British and the Boers. He put down the Rand Revolt in 1922, and is the only person to sign the charters of both the U.N. and the League of Nations.
This later South African head of state shared the 1993 Nobel Peace Prize with his successor, Nelson Mandela.
Identify this 1966 play whose protagonists are ambushed by pirates while traveling to England after watching a performance of The Murder of Gonzago.
Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead is the most famous work by this Czech-British playwright of Travesties, Arcadia, and The Coast of Utopia.

Esme identifies the Piper as Pink Floyd member Syd Barrett in this Stoppard play, which also sees the Ph.D student Jan become a devotee of the Plastic People of the Universe and a signatory of Charter 77 after returning to Czechoslovakia from Cambridge.
Name these devices used in the analytical technique of measuring the heat changes of a reaction.
It is essential to know this value for the reference substance to measure the enthalpy. This quantity is defined as the number of joules needed to change an object's temperature by one degree.

Developed by Privalov and Monaselidze, this type of calorimetry involves performing the namesake action on the reference substance to acquire information on the change of temperature, then calculating the corresponding heat of reaction.

answers: Mexican-American [or Chicano or Chicana; prompt on "Latino/a"s or "Hispanics";]
parts: Name this ethnicity shared by Gary Soto, critical theorist Gloria Anzaldua, Autobiography of a Brown Buffalo author Oscar Zeta Acosta, and the author of The House on Mango Street.
The short story collection Woman Hollering Creek was written by this aforementioned Chicana author of The House on Mango Street, which she based loosely on her childhood in Chicago.
Tenorio Trementina schemes against the title curandera, who serves as a mentor to Antonia Marez y Luna, in this best-known novel by Chicano author Rodolfo Anaya.

answers: The BBC [or British Broadcasting Corporation; accept things like BBC News]
parts: Identify this anthropologist, the author of The Lucifer Effect.
Philip Zimbardo is best known for conducting a prison experiment at this California university.

A 2002 follow-up to the Stanford Prison Experiment was conducted by this organization. Thomas Hajkowski wrote about how this institution associated with Received Pronunciation shaped national identity, especially in its early promotion of imperialism.

answers: Charles Darwin's theory of evolution through natural selection [accept natural selection]
Ã©lan vital [prompt on translations such as "vital force" or "vital spirit"]
parts: Name this scientific theory whose merits were defended by Thomas Henry Huxley in an 1860 debate against preacher Samuel Wilberforce.
Darwin criticized this British thinker for starting "social Darwinism," which this man expounded in his book Social Statics. This man coined the phrase "survival of the fittest."
Later, Henri Bergson argued that this mystical force influenced the increasing complexity of organisms over time. Bergson argued for this force in his book Creative Evolution.
Identify this literary character who becomes "unstuck in time" after being captured at the Battle of the Bulge.

Billy Pilgrim is the protagonist of Slaughterhouse-Five, a novel by this author of such science-fiction works as The Sirens of Titan. He invented a religious movement called Bokononism in his novel Cat's Cradle.
While on a plane to Dresden, Slaughterhouse-Five's narrator reads "The Waking," a villanelle written by this American poet of "Elegy for Jane" and "My Papa's Waltz."

answers: unity [or oneness, or being one with itself]
parts: Name this winter holiday for the black community, which lasts from December 26 to January 1.
This wooden candelabrum is the central object of Kwanzaa. Each of its seven candles stands for one of the holiday's Nguzo Saba, or Seven Principles.
This property of the black community is represented by the black candle on the kinara, between three green candles and three red ones. In Islam, God has this property, which is called tawhid.
Though this minimalist has on occasion written electronic music like Hoodoo Zephyr, he is more famous for orchestral works like Short Ride in a Fast Machine and the opera Nixon in China.

This composer included a part for the ondes martenot [ond mar-te-NO] is his monumental Turangalila-Symphonie. He also invented a series of synthetic scales and wrote Quartet for the End of Time while a prisoner during World War II.

One of the earliest electronic instruments is this one, which normally consists of two antennas hooked up to an electronic oscillator. By moving their hands relative to the antennae, the player is able to control the output pitch

answers: Crossing the T [or Capping the T]
parts: Successfully performing this maneuver allowed all of the guns in a fleet to focus on one enemy ship by advancing in front of an enemy column at a right angle. This action was employed against the Russians at the Battle of Tsushima.
The Roman navy employed the corvus during the first of these wars fought against Carthage.
The German navy found brief success in 1942 when it started organizing its U-Boats into groups with this name.
Name this physical force that results from a string of some sort pulling on another physical object. It is often abbreviated "T."
Tensile forces are one way to deform materials. Materials that are able to revert back to their original shape once the stress and strain have been removed are described by this term.
In contrast to elasticity, this word describes materials that are permanently deformed after stress or strain has been applied to them.

answers: Parnassus School [or Parnassianism; or Parnassism; accept other word forms]
parts: Lasting from roughly 1770 to 1848, this pan-European, heavily emotional, nature-praising literary movement was exemplified in France by Lamartine and Chateaubriand. Another adherent, William Wordsworth, described its poetry as "the spontaneous overflow of powerful feelings."

Between Romanticism and Symbolism came this formal literary style, named after a mythological location and inspired by Theophile Gautier's "art for art's sake" doctrine. Its champions included the first Nobel Laureate in literature, Sully Prudhomme.
Andre Breton was a leading light of this movement, writing both of its manifestos and pioneering its characteristic technique of "automatic writing" with his book The Magnetic Fields.
Name this relationship between two organisms, one of which benefits at the expense of the other, as in fleas with respect to humans.
Cuckoos exhibit this form of parasitism by laying eggs in the nests of other bird species so they can spend more time gathering food or reproducing.

Parasite-host interactions result in a constant process of natural selection as one tries to outdo the other, thus validating this hypothesis, named for a Lewis Carroll character, which states that organisms must constantly evolve merely to survive.

answers: Theodor Mommsen [or Christian Matthias Theodor Mommsen]
parts: Perceived antipathy towards the Byzantine Empire and open assignation of blame to the rise of Christianity are among the criticisms that have attended this man's magnum opus, The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire.

This ancient Roman author of a biography of Agricola and the Histories analyzed the Empire from the reign of Tiberius to that of Nero in his Annals, which also briefly mentions the execution of Christ.
The most famous accomplishment of this German scholar and archaeologist is his three-volume History of Rome, which contributed to his being awarded the 1902 Nobel Prize in Literature.

answers: herpes simplex viruses [or HSV-1; or HSV-2]
parts: Name these viruses, one of which causes most cold sores, and the other, which causes lesions to appear around the genitalia.

Another herpes virus, the varicella zoster virus, causes a facial nerve infection that is symptomatically very similar to this disease, whose suffers cannot control their facial muscles on the affected side.
Herpes zoster-associated encephalitis often causes the destruction of this substance in affected cells. Leukodystrophies impair the growth and development of this substance.

answers: Jean Anouilh [or Jean-Marie-Lucien-Pierre Anouilh; pronounced roughly like "Ah-NOOee-uh", but accept "Ahn-wee" or any other phonetic pronunciations]
Thomas Ã  Becket [or Thomas Becket; or Saint Thomas of Canterbury; prompt on "Saint Thomas"]
parts: Identify this Sophocles play in which the title daughter of Oedipus hangs herself after Creon refuses to let her properly bury Polynices.
This 20th-century French playwright attacked Vichy collaborators in his 1943 adaptation of Sophocles's Antigone. He also wrote Traveler Without Baggage and The Lark.
A Jean Anouilh play subtitled "or the Honor of God" is both about and titled for this "troublesome priest", whose assassination is also the subject of T.S. Eliot's play Murder in the Cathedral.
Identify this explorer who claimed what was likely Newfoundland, Labrador or Cape Breton Island for England.
John Cabot's son, Sebastian, created a celebrated world map for this monarch, who founded the Church of England after brooming Catherine of Aragon for Anne Boleyn.

This later explorer painstakingly documented that there was no link between Hudson Bay and the west coast of North America on a namesake expedition in the late 18th century. He lends his name to an island located near Nootka Sound.
